channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: 在上一任总理的领导下，巴勒斯坦权力机构的特点是部长之间争斗不休，完全无法进行任何有意义的改革。他的继任者会有更好的表现吗？ 👇
item.description:
Under its last prime minister, the Palestinian Authority was defined by feuding between ministers and a complete failure to enact any meaningful reforms. Will his replacement fare any better? https://t.co/BL5CcCps9n 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 纳伦德拉-莫迪（Narendra Modi）能否赢得印度较富裕、受教育程度较高的邦？经济学人》与泰米尔纳德邦的印度人民党首领一起踏上了竞选之路，以了解赢得南部地区支持的战斗👇。
item.description:
Can Narendra Modi woo India’s richer, better-educated states? The Economist went on the campaign trail with the head of the BJP in Tamil Nadu to understand the battle to win over the south https://t.co/mbO4yZZf9P 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 很快，电动汽车将使用多种不同类型的电池。出于成本或性能的考虑，所有这些电池都使用不同的化学成分 👇。
item.description:
Soon electric vehicles will be using many different types of battery. All of them use different chemistries for cost or performance https://t.co/lgPJZ7RVe8 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 印尼新总统希望自己的国家发挥更大的地缘政治作用。普拉博沃-苏比安托的外交政策将是怎样的？ 👇
item.description:
Indonesia’s new president wants his country to play a bigger geopolitical role. What will Prabowo Subianto’s foreign policy look like? https://t.co/btyLrpARMR 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 与以色列和哈马斯战争中的许多事件一样，踩踏和枪击事件背后的事实注定仍会引起激烈争论。然而，这场悲剧的重要性将远远超出眼前的生命损失。
item.description:
As with many events in the war between Israel and Hamas, the facts behind the stampede and shooting are destined to remain fiercely contested. Nonetheless this tragedy’s importance will go far beyond the immediate loss of life https://t.co/a4iooRIP2L

Image: Getty Images pic.twitter.com/r0bBBr20JI

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 在音乐流媒体服务的世界里，几乎任何歌曲都只需点击几下即可获取。然而，人们仍然挤满了汗流浃背的地下室和泥泞的田野，聆听他们喜爱的音乐家的演奏。神经科学可以帮助解释为什么演出仍在继续👇。
item.description:
In a world of music streaming services, access to almost any song is just a few clicks away. Yet people still fill sweaty basements and muddy fields to hear their favourite musicians play.

Neuroscience can help explain why the gig lives on https://t.co/ldfGlPpcKa 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 理查德-尼克松发起美国禁毒战争已有 50 多年，胜利似乎比以往任何时候都更加遥远。仅靠镇压是无法奏效的 👇
item.description:
It is over 50 years since Richard Nixon initiated America’s war on drugs, and victory seems further away than ever. Suppression alone won’t do the job https://t.co/AHGVhtgIcI 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 伊朗令中东闻风丧胆，其政权却在国内腐烂。假选举显示神职人员如何失去公众支持 👇
item.description:
As Iran scares the Middle East, its regime rots at home. Phoney elections show how the clerics have lost public support https://t.co/OzrLaa64Zf 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 这个 #BuildABritishVoter 工具太酷了！@JamesFransham 根据近 10 万名英国人的意见建立了一个模型，让您可以探索构成英国选民的人口群体，@_rospearce 将其变成了这个令人上瘾的互动工具：
item.description:
This #BuildABritishVoter tool is so cool!@JamesFransham built a model based on the views of nearly 100,000 Britons that lets you explore the demographic groups that make up Britain’s electorate, and @_rospearce turned it into this addictive interactive:https://t.co/y1KOkjeajw pic.twitter.com/cBOoqAArm0

— Alex Selby-Boothroyd (@AlexSelbyB) February 28, 2024

item.title: 据哈马斯管理的卫生部称，约 112 人在枪击和踩踏事件中丧生。虽然目前的报道相互矛盾，但有三件事仍然是明确的👇。
item.description:
Some 112 people have been killed after a shooting and a stampede, according to the Hamas-run health ministry. While current reports are contradictory, three things remain clear https://t.co/g45KFjeqau 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 周一巴黎峰会后，我写了一篇关于法德争执的文章。在慕尼黑，我对德国官员认为法国对乌克兰的援助不足所表现出的恼怒感到震惊。另一方面，肖尔茨本周受到了金牛座的青睐。
item.description:
I wrote on the Franco-German row after Monday's Paris summit. I was struck, in Munich, at the irritation among German officials over what they saw as the shortfall on French aid to Ukraine. On the other hand, Scholz has been hoist by Taurus this week. https://t.co/9WmaAY3FR3

— Shashank Joshi (@shashj) February 29, 2024

item.title: 本周的 "查理曼大帝 "主题是欧洲的矮小天际线。欧洲是摩天大楼建造者遗忘的大陆。全球最高的 1000 座建筑中，只有 7 座位于欧盟。这是一种幸运，还是其雄心不足的另一个标志？
item.description:
This week's Charlemagne is on Europe's stubby skyline. It is the continent skyscraper-builders forgot. Only seven of the world's tallest 1000 buildings are in the EU. Is that a blessing or another sign of its deficient ambition?

https://t.co/4HFLrrz01d

— Stanley Pignal (@spignal) February 29, 2024

item.title: 在经济持续放缓的今天，怀念中国经济繁荣时期是一种普遍现象。在 "鼓楼 "节目中@aliceysu 和 @DSORennie 观看了一部电影，影片展现了这一时期的黑暗面。收听播客 🎧
item.description:
Nostalgia for China’s boom years is common today, as the economy continues to slow. On “Drum Tower” @aliceysu and @DSORennie watch a film that shows a darker side of this period. Listen to the podcast https://t.co/AqsabTTHYS 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 科学家们希望通过治疗导致 "接吻病 "的 Epstein-Barr 病毒来解决多发性硬化症问题。疫苗和抗病毒药物已在试验中 👇。
item.description:
Scientists want to tackle multiple sclerosis by treating the Epstein-Barr virus that causes “kissing disease”. Vaccines and antivirals are already undergoing trials https://t.co/l37O3HVTPw 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 洪都拉斯前总统胡安-奥兰多-埃尔南德斯的案件提出了一个问题：为什么美国很难在禁毒战争中找到值得信赖的盟友？
item.description:
The case against the former Honduran president, Juan Orlando Hernández, raises the question of why it is hard for the United States to find trustworthy allies in the war on drugs https://t.co/028cMNNMQc 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 那些想对俄罗斯被冻结的资金采取行动的人是对的，但如何采取行动关系重大。直接扣押资产将是一个错误👇。
item.description:
Those who want to do something with Russia’s frozen money are right, but how it is done matters greatly. Seizing the assets outright would be a mistake https://t.co/fprevfIp94 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 像 ChatGPT 这样的人工智能模型有胡编乱造的倾向。这些幻觉可以控制吗？ 👇
item.description:
AI models like ChatGPT have a tendency to make things up.

Can these hallucinations be controlled? https://t.co/Pwx2b7YxVS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 一位前政治犯在客座文章中指出，在阿列克谢-纳瓦尔尼去世后，西方需要重新发现对俄罗斯持不同政见者的关注
item.description:
The West needs to rediscover its concern for Russian dissidents in the wake of Alexei Navalny’s death, argues a former political prisoner in a guest essay https://t.co/GmaTIpCKjS

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 阿根廷的足球俱乐部正在衰落，尽管其国家队在世界上名列前茅。阿根廷最近当选的总统哈维尔-米莱（Javier Milei）认为，私人投资的缺乏是造成俱乐部足球状况不佳的罪魁祸首⚽️。
item.description:
Argentina’s football clubs are in decline, even as its national team ranks best in the world. Javier Milei, the country’s recently elected president, believes that a lack of private investment is to blame for the sorry state of club football https://t.co/Pvpnnpb2KM ⚽️

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 格兰瑟姆（Grantham）是东米德兰兹郡的一个小镇，拥有 4.5 万人口，这里的居民不久将选出半个世纪以来的首次地方议会。这将引起英国保守党内历史爱好者的共鸣👇。
item.description:
The people of Grantham, a town of 45,000 in the East Midlands, will elect soon a local council for the first time in half a century. This will resonate will resonate with history buffs in Britain’s Conservative Party https://t.co/o3h4v27d9V 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 巴西正在经历经济复兴，亚马逊地区的森林砍伐也已大幅减缓。但总统的口误正在破坏他的成就👇。
item.description:
Brazil is experiencing an economic revival and deforestation in the Amazon has slowed dramatically. But the president’s gaffes are undermining his accomplishments https://t.co/3vBKKHWjVJ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 阿列克谢-纳瓦尔尼将作为一个具有非凡勇气的人而受到赞颂。人们将铭记他的死，因为这说明了弗拉基米尔-普京的什么，这预示着俄罗斯的什么，以及这对世界提出了什么要求 👇。
item.description:
Alexei Navalny will be celebrated as a man of remarkable courage. His death will be remembered for what it says about Vladimir Putin, what it portends for Russia and what it demands of the world https://t.co/aJRjL8WiJN 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 大多数人都知道，印度是一个正在崛起的经济巨人，其总理纳伦德拉-莫迪是几十年来印度最有权势的人。但鲜为人知的是，发展和身份政治如何助长了第三种趋势：南北分裂日益加剧👇。
item.description:
Most people know that India is a rising economic giant, and that its prime minister, Narendra Modi, is its most powerful in decades.

Less well known is how development and identity politics are fuelling a third trend: a growing north-south split https://t.co/YReP87lqnl 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 其他图像生成工具因被要求提供企业家或医生的图像时往往显示白人男性而受到批评，而谷歌的双子座却掉进了另一个陷阱👇。
item.description:
While other image-generation tools have been criticised because they tend to show white men when asked for images of entrepreneurs or doctors, Google’s Gemini has fallen into another trap https://t.co/UVCLwUCZ0u 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 不断变化的英国选民正在推动工党走向胜利。我们的数据显示，工党正在建立一个非常广泛的选举联盟📈。
item.description:
A changing British electorate is propelling Labour toward victory. Our data shows that the party is forging a remarkably broad electoral coalition https://t.co/FbqZO6vpRZ 📈

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 还记得 "蒙迪欧人 "吗？几乎每一次英国大选，政客和媒体都会找到一种新的刻板印象来解释选举结果。我们采取了一种更细化的方法。在这里使用我们的互动工具来#BuildABritishVoter（打造英国选民） 🗳️
item.description:
Remember “Mondeo man”? With almost every British general election, politicians and the press find a new stereotype to explain the outcome.

We’ve taken a more granular approach. Use our interactive tool to #BuildABritishVoter here https://t.co/JUt3Slc21F 🗳️

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 英国一半以上的池塘已经消失。几乎--它们的来世令人惊讶。即使在它们消失 150 年后，"幽灵池塘 "也会在景观上留下水的印记 👇。
item.description:
More than half of Britain’s ponds have disappeared. Almost—they have a surprising afterlife. Even 150 years after they pass, “ghost ponds” can leave a watery mark on the landscape https://t.co/6VKT3vg6ch 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 伊朗毛拉曾经努力提高选民投票率。现在，他们对自己的不受欢迎已经心灰意冷，几乎懒得去管了。乏善可陈的竞选活动说明了什么？ 法新社
item.description:
Iran’s mullahs once strove to increase voter turnout. Now they are so resigned to their unpopularity that they hardly bother. What does the lacklustre election campaign say about the state of the regime? https://t.co/VGPUfPKbjL

Photo: AFP pic.twitter.com/aEHBug1sCb

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 阿列克谢-纳瓦尔尼抵制弗拉基米尔-普京政权所代表的一切：任人唯亲、贪婪、道德败坏。他知道，他将因此受到骚扰、监禁和封口。甚至会被杀害。但他不怕死。他无暇顾及恐惧。
item.description:
Alexei Navalny resisted everything Vladimir Putin’s regime stood for: cronyism, greed, moral rot.

He knew that for this he would be harassed, imprisoned and silenced. Killed, even. But he wasn’t afraid of death. Fear was something he had no time for https://t.co/G63vlJZmNS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024

item.title: 试管婴儿是民主党人的热门话题。堕胎可能不是 👇
item.description:
IVF is a slam-dunk issue for Democrats. Abortion may not be https://t.co/8d8vf3SyK5 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 29, 2024
